**PATIENT INFORMATION:**
- Name: Michael Torres
- MRN: [REDACTED]
- DOB: [REDACTED]
- Date of Procedure: [REDACTED]
- Procedure Time: 09:00-10:30
- Procedure Duration: 90 minutes

**INSTITUTION:[REDACTED]

**ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:** Dr. Lisa Anderson, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)  
**ASSISTANT:** Dr. James Park, MD (Pulmonary Fellow)  
**ANESTHESIA:** Dr. Susan Lee, MD (MAC)

**INDICATION:**
66-year-old male with exudative left pleural effusion, etiology unclear after two non-diagnostic thoracenteses. CT findings concerning for pleural malignancy. Pleuroscopy for tissue diagnosis and talc pleurodesis if appropriate.

**PRE-PROCEDURE:**
- Complete H&P, informed consent obtained with detailed discussion of risks/benefits
- Timeout completed with entire team
- CT chest reviewed: left pleural effusion with subtle pleural enhancement
- PET-CT: Moderate FDG uptake in left pleura (SUV 4.2)
- Labs: WBC 7.8K, Platelets 298K, INR 1.1, Creatinine 0.9
- Pulmonary function tests: FEV1 68% predicted, FVC 72% predicted
- Vital signs: BP 136/82, HR 74, SpO2 94% on RA

**ANESTHESIA:**
- Monitored anesthesia care
- Propofol infusion with fentanyl boluses
- Local anesthesia supplementation
- Patient maintained spontaneous respiration

**PROCEDURE DETAILS:**

*Patient Positioning:*
- Right lateral decubitus position
- Left arm supported overhead
- Standard ASA monitoring

*Access:*
- Ultrasound guidance used for safe entry site id[REDACTED]
- Left lateral chest, 6th intercostal space, mid-axillary line
- Chlorhexidine skin prep
- Local anesthesia: 25 mL 1% lidocaine
- 10 mm incision
- Blunt dissection through subcutaneous tissue and intercostal muscles
- Pleura entered, 650 mL clear yellow fluid evacuated
- 10 mm trocar placed

*Pleuroscopy Findings:*
- Rigid pleuroscope (7mm, 0-degree) introduced
- Comprehensive pleural survey conducted
- **Visceral Pleura:** Normal appearance, smooth, glistening, no nodules or masses
- **Parietal Pleura:** Focal area of pleural thickening and inflammation in posterolateral chest wall (approximately 4x6 cm area). Multiple small vessels visible. No discrete masses.
- **Diaphragm:** Normal appearance
- **Lung:** Good lung expansion, no evidence of trapped lung
- **Overall Impression:** Focal inflammatory changes, possible pleuritis vs. early malignancy

*Biopsies:*
- 8 parietal pleural biopsies obtained from abnormal areas using rigid forceps
- 2 biopsies from normal-appearing parietal pleura for comparison
- Biopsies adequate depth including muscle layer
- Good hemostasis maintained

*Therapeutic Intervention:*
- Decision made to proceed with talc pleurodesis given adequate lung expansion
- Complete drainage of pleural fluid: total 1,100 mL
- 5 grams sterile graded talc insufflated uniformly throughout pleural space
- Talc distributed to all surfaces under direct visualization
- 24 French chest tube placed under direct vision
- Chest tube positioned along posterolateral chest wall

*Complications During Procedure:* None

**POST-PROCEDURE:**
- Patient transferred to PACU in stable condition
- Chest tube to water seal with -20 cm H2O suction
- Post-procedure chest X-ray: appropriate chest tube placement, talc distribution visible, small residual effusion
- Patient comfortable, no respiratory distress
- Vital signs: BP 128/74, HR 78, SpO2 96% on 2L NC
- Pain well controlled (2/10)

**SPECIMENS SENT:**
- Pleural biopsies (10 specimens) - histopathology, tissue for culture if needed
- Pleural fluid - cytology, cultures (aerobic, anaerobic, AFB, fungal)

**IMMEDIATE ASSESSMENT:**
Successful medical pleuroscopy with talc pleurodesis. Pleural findings suggestive of inflammatory process; biopsies obtained for definitive diagnosis. Good lung expansion allows for pleurodesis attempt.

**COMPLICATIONS:** None

**DISPOSITION:** Admitted for post-pleurodesis monitoring and chest tube management

**PLAN:**
- Chest tube to water seal after 24 hours if output decreasing
- Monitor for post-pleurodesis fever (expected)
- Acetaminophen and NSAIDs for fever/pain management
- Serial chest X-rays daily
- Remove chest tube when output <150 mL/24 hours, no air leak, and lung expanded
- Expected chest tube duration: 2-4 days
- Await pathology results (3-5 days)
- Discharge when chest tube removed and patient stable
- Follow up in 2 weeks with imaging to assess pleurodesis success
